choices.text: Graft contains hairs and sweat gland
Thicker graft heals with less contracture

questions.text: All statements are correct regarding split thickness skin grafting except?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 46 Burns, Pg: 676

choices.text: Full-thickness skin grafts are harvested to incorporate the whole dermis
Composite graft contains epidermis and only part of dermis

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding full-thickness skin graft except?
questions.solution:
• Full-thickness grafts are harvested to incorporate the whole dermis, with the underlying fat trimmed away - unless elements of fat (or even cartilage as well) are deliberately left attached to form a composite graft.
  • Full-thickness and composite grafts require the most careful handling and postoperative nursing to help ensure that they ‘take’ in their transplanted site.

FULL THICKNESS SKIN GRAFT

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 687

choices.text: Split-thickness graft initially survive by inosculation
Split thickness graft survive initially by imbibition of plasma
After 72 hours fine anastamotic connections are made.
Split-thickness skin grafts are best to cover exposed tendon, cartilage or cortical bone.

questions.text: All statements are incorrect regarding skin graft survival except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Split-thickness skin grafts survive initially by imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.

Option C: After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which lead to inosculation of blood.

Option D: Because only tissues that produce granulation will support a graft, it is usually contraindicated to use grafts to cover exposed tendons, cartilage or cortical bone.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 686

choices.text: Split-thickness skin grafts are also called thiersch grafts.
Full-thickness skin grafts are also known as wolfe grafts.
Full thickness skin grafts can use to cover all sizes of wound
Grafts are tissues that are transferred without their blood supply.

questions.text: All the statements are correct regarding graft except?
questions.solution:
• Grafts are tissues that are transferred without their blood supply, which therefore have to revascularise once they are in a new site. They include the following:
  • Split-thickness skin grafts (of varying thickness). These are sometimes called Thiersch grafts. They are used to cover all sizes of wound, are of limited durability and will contract. They may be used to provide valuable temporary wound closure before better cosmetic secondary correction after rehabilitation.
  • Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe grafts). Used for smaller areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin that will not contract is required (such as fingers, eyelids, facial parts)

DIFFERENCE BETWEEN FULL THICKNESS SKIN GRAFTING AND SPLIT THICKNESS SKIN GRAFTING

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 686-687.

choices.text: No specific relationship to where the blood supply enters
Length to breadth ratio should be more than 1.5:1
Length to breath ratio can be extended by delaying flap

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding random flap except?
questions.solution:
• Random flaps. Three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters; the length to breadth ratio is no more than 1.5:1.
  • This pattern can be lengthened by ‘delaying’ the flap, a process in which the cuts are partially made and the flap is part lifted at a first operation; it is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle.
  • At a second procedure, it is raised further and finally transferred.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 690

questions.text: Identify the flap in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Axial flaps. Much longer flaps, based on known blood vessels supplying the skin.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Page Number-690.

choices.text: Random flap: Specific relationship from where blood supply enters
Free flap: can be swung around stalk
Pedicled flap: blood supply isolated, disconnected and then reconnected
Composite flap: various tissues are transferred together

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect regarding flap except?
questions.solution:
Composite flaps: Various tissues are transferred together, often skin with bone or muscle (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively).

Option A: Random flaps: Three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters; the length to breadth ratio is no more than 1.5:1. This pattern can be lengthened by ‘delaying’ the flap, a process in which the cuts are partially made and the flap is part lifted at a first operation; it is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle. At a second procedure, it is raised further and finally transferred.

Option B: Free flaps: The blood supply has been isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site

Option C: Pedicled/islanded flaps: The axial blood supply of these flaps means that they can be swung round on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ so that the business end of the skin being transferred can have the pedicle buried

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 690

questions.text: Identify device shown in image below
questions.solution:
Tissue Expanansion-Tissue expansion is a technique that increases the amount of tissue in a surgical flap by first plac­ing an inflatable device into the tissue beneath the planned flap and gradually expanding the tissue by regular inflation. Staged reconstruction using tissue expansion can significantly increase the amount of local, well-matched tissue for transfer while decreasing donor site morbidity. The most common method of skin expansion involves the placement of an inflatable silicon elastomer similar to a balloon with a filling port that is gener­ally positioned in an easily accessible location beneath the skin. After wound healing, the device is gradually inflated by serial injection of sterile saline solution into the filling port. The

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 689

questions.text: Identify device shown in below image
questions.solution:
Vacuum-assisted closure

  • The use of negative pressure applied to a tissue defect has positive effects on wound closure, as well as making difficult and complex wounds more manageable during the early stages of granulation.
  • Exudate is removed and the suction pressure affects angiogenesis and tissue regeneration. The technique can be applied as part of early wound management before definitive surgical closure has been planned, or in some cases to avoid the need for surgery altogether. The foam sponge dressing is connected by a tube to a negative pressure pump that can be controlled to give intermittent suction

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery

choices.text: Split-thickness skin graft can be expand from ratio of 1:1.5 to 1:6
Most used donor site is thigh
Vascularisation is not needed for graft take on a bed
Graft failure commonly caused by pus, exudates or residual dead tissue beneath the skin.

questions.text: All are the following statements are correct regarding split thickness skin graft except?
questions.solution:
Split-thickness skin grafts

  • Split-thickness skin grafts are taken with either hand-held or powered skin knives.

The most used donor site is the thigh, with the buttock preferable in children and cosmetically sensitive individuals. For larger grafts, almost any flat surface can be harvested, including the scalp if shaved (a very good and useful donor site).

  • The thickness of the graft harvested, ease of graft ‘take’ and donor site healing must be weighed against the lack of durability of thin split-thickness skin grafts.
  • Split grafts can be perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’; they can be further meshed to allow expansion.
  • This is carried out on a device that cuts a series of slits along the skin, allowing it to expand from a ratio of anything from 1:1.5 to about 1:6.
  • Grafts will only take on a bed on which they can become vascularised. Preparation of the wound bed is therefore an essential part of a successful graft.
  • Graft failure is commonly caused by pus, exudate or residual dead tissue beneath the skin, haematoma or shearing forces. A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage success.

Split-thickness skin grafts consist of epidermis and a variable amount of dermis and are sometimes referred to as Thiersch grafts. They are commonly harvested from the thigh using a dermatome or graft knife to achieve a consistent depth. It is relatively simple to harvest large areas of skin to reconstruct sizeable defects such as those following a significant burn injury

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 686

questions.text: Presence of which microorganism is contraindication for split thickness skin grafting?
questions.solution:
• The group A β-haemolytic Streptococcus can destroy split grafts completely (and also convert a donor site to a full-thickness defect) and so the presence of this microorganism is a contraindication to grafting.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 686

choices.text: Transposition flap: most basic design, leaving graftable donor site
Z- plasty : for lengthening of scar and tissue

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding local flaps except?
questions.solution:
Local flaps

A local flap is raised next to a tissue defect in order to reconstruct it

  1. Basic patterns include
    • Transposition flap. The most basic design, leaving a graftable donor site
    • Z-plasty. For lengthening scars or tissues;
    • Rhomboid flap. For cheek, temple, back and flat surface defects;
    • Rotation flap. For convex surfaces;
    • Advancement flap. For flexor surfaces; may need triangles excised at the base to make it work (commonly called Burow's triangles);
    • V-to-Y advancement. Commonly used for fingertips and extremities;
    • Bilobed flap. For convex surfaces, especially the nose
    • Bipedicle flap. For eyelids, rarely elsewhere.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 691

questions.solution:
V-to-Y advancement. Commonly used for fingertips and extremities;

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 692

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding necrotising fasciitis except?
questions.solution:
Skin and soft-tissue infections can be localised or spreading, necrotising or non-necrotising. Localised or spreading non-necrotising infections usually respond to broad-spectrum antibiotics. Localised necrotising infections need surgical debridement as well as antibiotic therapy. Spreading necrotising soft-tissue infection constitutes a life-threatening surgical emergency, requiring immediate resuscitation, intravenous antibiotic therapy and urgent surgical intervention with radical debridement.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 644

questions.text: Identify skin infection shown in image below
questions.solution:
Erysipelas

  • Erysipelas is a sharply demarcated streptococcal infection of the superficial lymphatics, usually associated with broken skin on the face. The area affected is erythematous and oedematous.
  • The patient may be febrile and have a leucocytosis.
  • Prompt administration of broad spectrum antibiotics after swabbing the area for culture and sensitivity is usually all that is necessary.

Erysipelas is a sharply demarcated streptococcal infection of the superfcial lymphatics, usually associated with broken skin on the face. The area affected is erythematous and oedematous. The patient may be febrile and have a leukocytosis. Prompt administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics after swabbing the area for culture and sensitivity is usually all that is necessary.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 644

questions.text: All of the following are localized variety of Basal cell carcinoma except?
questions.solution:
BCC can be divided into

  • localised (nodular; nodulocystic; cystic; pigmented and naevoid) and
  • generalised (superficial: multifocal and superficial spreading; or infiltrative: morphoeic, ice pick and cicatrizing).

Nodular and nodulocystic variants account for 90% of BCC.

Typical naevi can be sporadic or familial (familial atypical multiple mole-melanoma [FAMMM] syndrome). Possession of more than five lesions confers a relative risk of melanoma six times greater than usual; within FAMMM syndrome, they confer a 100% risk of malignant melanoma and patients with FAMMM syndrome should be screened for melanoma 6-monthly, lifelong.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 651-652

choices.text: Superficial spreading form is most common type
Breslow thickness has no role in prognosis
Sentinel lymphnode biopsy useful for staging

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding malignant melanoma except
questions.solution:
A small proportion of malignant melanoma is genetically mediated and develops at an earlier age. People at most risk of developing malignantmelanoma include: those with genetic syndromes; those with a past history of malignant melanoma or with a first-degree relative who has malignant melanoma; those who have more than 30 sun-acquired naevi or a history of five-significant sunburns before the age of 16; fair-skinned/ red-haired people living close to the equator; anyone with excessive UVR exposure (environmental or salon-delivered); or anyone with immunosuppression (which increases malignant melanoma incidence 20- to 30-fold). Male gender and solitary living are both associated with thicker melanomas at diagnosis. In women, higher socioeconomic status is positively correlated with developing melanoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 656

questions.text: Malignant melanomas under the finger nail are usually of which type?
questions.solution:
• MM under the finger nail are usually SSM rather than ALM. For finger or toe nail lesions it is vital to biopsy the nail matrix, rather than just the pigment on the nail plate.
  • A classical feature of a subungual melanoma is Hutchinson’s sign: nail fold pigmentation that widens progressively to produce a triangular pigmented macule with associated nail dystrophy.
  • The differential diagnosis is ‘benign racial melanonychia’, which produces a linear dark streak under a nail in a dark skinned individual. Malignancy is unlikely if the nail fold is uninvolved

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 657

questions.text: Single most important prognostic index in melanoma?
questions.solution:
• The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index in melanoma, outweighing both tumour and host factors. The number of affected nodes and the presence of extranodal extension are also significant outcome predictors.
  • Once regional nodes are clinically involved, 70-85% of patients will have occult distant metastases.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 658

questions.text: Which one of the following agent used as adjuvant therapy in management of malignant melanoma?
questions.solution:
• When mutation locks B-RAF protein signalling to 'on', it affects the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cellular pathway, promoting initiation, malignant transformation, tumour progression and metastasis in the 50% of MM with B-RAF V600 mutations.
  • Targeted therapy in stage IV melanoma using dabrafenib or vemurafenib, which block B-RAF action has shown promising results with metastatic melanoma.
  • Trametinib has a different action on the MAPK pathway: stopping cell growth and promoting apoptosis. Combined use with dabrafenib to counter acquired tumour resistance via MAPK pathway reactivation, shows promising results in stage 4 disease.
  • Also, selective immune checkpoint inhibitors ipilimumab or nivolimumab demonstrate benefit in metastatic or unresectable melanoma.

Malignant melanoma

  • Rising incidence
  • Genetic and acquired risk factors
  • Superfcial spreading form the most common
  • Breslow thickness is the most important prognostic indicator

Sentinel node biopsy (SNB) is useful for staging

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 658

choices.text: 70% resolved by 7 year of age
Occurs most commonly on head and neck
Boys are affected more as compared to girls

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding condition given in image below except?
questions.solution:
• Capillary haemangioma (strawberry naevus)
  • This is the commonest ‘birth mark’, occurring most commonly on the head and neck.

90% appear at birth, and, as a consequence of intravascular thrombosis, fibrosis and mast cell infiltration, 10% resolve each subsequent year, with 70% resolved by 7 years old.

Whites skin is affected most commonly and girls are affected three times more than boys.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 660

questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 658
